lines.text: We buried brother Jacob here. I had a brother Aaron beside him. They had enough of guns and killing. The dead don't have much.
I remember you, at Fort Bliss.
That's my trouble. Everybody remembers me at Fort Bliss.

[referring to Maddox]
Who's he, some bounty hunter or something?
Don't make an enemy of him, storekeeper. Step wide of him.
Vern, did you feel the world turn beneath your feet?
Is there something you wanted?
Can't say there is, minister.
A man comes to the house of God, he comes to seek.
I'm not a believing man, minister.
Then why have you come?
A man doesn't see many churches like this in a town like Sabbath.
The shape of the house of God is unimportant.

That's not so, minister. The kind of church man builds to pray in tells you a lot about the man. Further south there are some fine old adobe churches - Mexican. They're cool and dark inside. Give a man peace. They're made for kneelin'. This one's made for standin' upright.
There is no easy comfort from God.
Why do you ask me?
I figured you'd be the one man in this town who'd find it difficult to lie to me.
I don't like men sweatin' fear in my house!

[taking offense]
You pay me, Mr. Bronson, and I eat your dirt, but that don't make what you say right!

[making an ultimatun]
You've got two ways to move, lawman. Run or take me!
I don't call the numbers, Ryan. I never drew first on a man in my life. That's the only way to stay clean - you play it by the rules. Without the rules, you're nothing!
He didn't have a chance! You don't even care, do you Maddox?
No... No, I don't care. You say he didn't have a chance. He went for his gun first. When he does that, he uses up all his chances.
I know what you're doin' is wrong, Maddox. You were wrong in San Acoma. You're wrong here.
Not from where I stand.
You can't see from where you stand.

I'm a lawman. Do you know what a lawman is, Crowe? He's a killer of men. That's what the job calls for. There are new ways to put it, but it reads the same. That's the difference between us, and it's all the difference I need.
Choctaw is a gunhand. Bronson likes his work. Decker is a shadow walker. He walks big when he's with Choctaw, but a back-shooter inside.
On the way back, they hit a town called Bannock. They drank their fill, had their women, shot up the town - all just cowboy fun. They killed an old man.
You and I sit at the same table, Jared. The virtuous need us, but they can't stand the smell.
Marc was a good man with a gun.
He was a big mouth who thought he was a good man with a gun. There's a cold hole in the ground between the two.
It took guns to get the land, guns to keep it, guns to make things grow. The guns that pride called out... and each time we buried the cost.
He'll go back to Bannock and stand trial.
Will they hang him?
The circuit judge is no hanging judge. In fact, a man like Bronson could buy him cheap.
I don't mean just the judge. I mean the town, the good people with the rope.
It's my town, Laura. Nobody gets a mob rope in my town. You know that. I give you my word. If he comes in peaceful, there will be no hurt come to him.
You never did give much away.

What do you want to do - ride into Sabbath and gun him down? Those days have passed. Times have changed. There are other ways. You buy him, and if he doesn't sell, you buy the man above him. Those killing days were for younger men.

It's always the same. If you post a man, he has to come into town to prove he's a man. Or you kill a man, he's got a friend or kin -- he just has to come against you... and for no reason... no reason that makes any sense. And it don't mean a damn to the man already in the ground. Nobody wins.
Ryan thinks you're pretty good. He says you could kill me anytime you wanted to. I see it different. I think I'm faster.
Are you asking me who's faster or whether I could kill you when I chose to? Because if it's the second, the answer is yes.
You're pretty damn sure.

I'm pretty damn sure. You think it's a game, don't you? A contest between gentlemen. You ever kill a man, Crowe? You're a cowman. You carry a gun for protection... snakes. You learn to use it sometimes fairly well; sometimes you become really good - but you're still a cowman.
You can't break the rules, Laura.
Oh, the rules! I forgot the rules. You think they change the killing? Because you never draw on a man first, you think that really matters? Do you know what they call you, Jared? The widowmaker!

It's a great life. If you were some cheap gunsel with a big name running out in front of you, they'd all be buying you drinks... rubbing up against you... fixing up what they're going to tell their kids and the ones who weren't there. But if you're a lawman, you're a disease. They need you, but they hate you.
It comes with the job.
Some men just go to things in a straight line, Mr. Bronson. They don't bend and they don't trade.
Are you telling me Maddox is like that?
He's got the mark.
That's too bad. Then he's going to buy himself a lot of pain.
A man gets caught in his own doing. You can't change what you are. And if you try, something always calls you back.
When it comes down to bedrock, my word don't call much, does it, Vince? I'm just hired help.
In every town Maddox has worked, the ground is full of men who were faster.
Yeah, well, I really am. And I aim to prove it, too.

It makes a great epitaph. You may be faster, Crowe. You may be better with a gun, but Maddox will kill you... and that's a fact. You'll be staring up at nothing before your gun ever got clear. I know what I'm talking about, Crowe. You may not rate me very high, but I know men like Maddox.
I'll tell you, Lucas, if I had somewhere to run, I'd run. But I don't, so I'll stand.
Any free land around here?

[Vernon doesn't answer]
I asked you a question, mister.
Only high up. South of the river there's some for the buyin'.
Good land?

[Contemptuously]
Men like you don't buy land, Maddox - you don't buy it, and you don't work it.
Fine people, the Commanches. Don't ever listen to anyone who talks down an Indian.
Would you have come, Laura, if you're man hadn't been on the list?
No. There's nothing left, Jared.
The great Cotton Ryan... you were good with a gun once, oh, you were beautiful. But Fort Bliss was a long time ago, wasn't it, Ryan?

Which one has the words? You're the store keeper, Luther Harris ain't it? Let me say them for you. You want me out of your town. What happened some other time some other place ain't your trouble. I've seen men like you in every town in the West. You want the law, but you want it to walk quiet. You don't want it to put a hole in your pocket. You take courage from each other and you come armed. Well, there are enough of you. All you need is one man with enough stomach to die first. I'm not leaving until what I came for is done. So if you plan to do anything about it do it now or go home.
